item.title: Differentiation and Integration
item.description: Dashboard Lesson 1 Lesson 2 Lesson 3 Lesson 4 Lesson 5 Lesson 6 Lesson 7 Lesson 8 Lesson 9 Lesson 10 Lesson 11 Lesson 12 Lesson 13 Lesson 14

item.title: Differentiation and Integration - Lesson 1
item.description: Dashboard –> Differentiation and Integration The derivative of a function Given a function $y = f(x)$. At every value of $x$, we can calculate the slope of the tangent line.

item.title: Differentiation and Integration - Lesson 10
item.description: Dashboard –> Differentiation and Integration Lucky case When the numerator is equal to the derivative of the denominator, then the primitive function is equal to the $\ln(\text{denominator}) + C$.

item.title: Differentiation and Integration - Lesson 11
item.description: Dashboard –> Differentiation and Integration More primitives arctangent We know that the derivative of $\arctan(x)$ is $\frac{1}{x^{2} + 1}$. Therefore:

item.title: Differentiation and Integration - Lesson 12
item.description: Dashboard –> Differentiation and Integration Partial integration Product rule We know how to use the product rule in differentiation: $$[f(x)\cdot g(x)]’ = f’(x)\cdot g(x) + f(x)\cdot g’(x)$$ We can also apply this rule in integration:

item.title: Differentiation and Integration - Lesson 13
item.description: Dashboard –> Differentiation and Integration Substitution Chain rule We know the chain rule in differentiation $$[(a+b)^{4}]’ = 4\cdot(a + b)^{3}\cdot[a + b]’$$ Therefore:

item.title: Differentiation and Integration - Lesson 14
item.description: Dashboard –> Differentiation and Integration The determined integral Solving an undertermined integral gives a collection of primitive functions. In real application we will need a determined integral, a number.

item.title: Differentiation and Integration - Lesson 2
item.description: Dashboard –> Differentiation and Integration The sum rule The derivative of the sum of two functions is the sum of the derivative of the two funtions.

item.title: Differentiation and Integration - Lesson 2 - Example 1
item.description: Dashboard –> Differentiation and Integration –> Lesson 2 $f(x) = \htmlClass{blue}{x^{2}}+ \htmlClass{seagreen}{sin(x)}$ $f(x) = \htmlClass{blue}{g(x)} + \htmlClass{seagreen}{h(x)}$ with: $g(x) = \htmlClass{blue}{x^{2}}$

item.title: Differentiation and Integration - Lesson 2 - Example 2
item.description: Dashboard –> Differentiation and Integration –> Lesson 2 $f(x) = \htmlClass{blue}{2x}\cdot \htmlClass{seagreen}{sin(x)}$ $f(x) = \htmlClass{blue}{g(x)} \cdot \htmlClass{seagreen}{h(x)}$ with: $g(x) = \htmlClass{blue}{2x}$

item.title: Differentiation and Integration - Lesson 3
item.description: Dashboard –> Differentiation and Integration Recap Constant multiplication: $[c\cdot f’]=c\cdot f’$ Sum: $[f + g]’ = f’ + g’$ Product: $[f\cdot g]’ = f’\cdot g + f\cdot g'$

item.title: Differentiation and Integration - Lesson 3 - Example 1
item.description: Dashboard –> Differentiation and Integration –> Lesson 3 $f(x) = \frac{\class{salmon}{2x + 3}}{\class{blue}{x^{2}+ 1}}$ $f(x) = \frac{\htmlClass{salmon}{t(x)}}{\htmlClass{blue}{n(x)}}$ With: $t(x) = \class{salmon}{2x + 3}$

item.title: Differentiation and Integration - Lesson 4
item.description: Dashboard –> Differentiation and Integration Recap Constant multiplication: $[c\cdot f’]=c\cdot f’$ Sum: $[f + g]’ = f’ + g’$ Product: $[f\cdot g]’ = f’\cdot g + f\cdot g’$

item.title: Differentiation and Integration - Lesson 4 - Example 1
item.description: Dashboard –> Differentiation and Integration –> Lesson 4 $\htmlClass{blue}{A(x)} = \htmlClass{blue}{2x + 5}$ $\htmlClass{seagreen}{B(x)} = \htmlClass{seagreen}{x^{2} + 1}$ $\htmlClass{seagreen}{B(\htmlClass{blue}{A(x)})} = \htmlClass{seagreen}{\htmlClass{blue}{A(x)}^{2}+ 1} = \htmlClass{seagreen}{\htmlClass{blue}{(2x + 5)}^{2}+ 1}$

item.title: Differentiation and Integration - Lesson 4 - Example 2
item.description: Dashboard –> Differentiation and Integration –> Lesson 4 $f(x) = \htmlClass{blue}{\sin(\htmlClass{seagreen}{2x + 3})}$ $f(x) = \htmlClass{blue}{A(\htmlClass{seagreen}{B(x)})}$ With: $\htmlClass{blue}{A(x)} = \htmlClass{blue}{\sin(x)}$

item.title: Differentiation and Integration - Lesson 5
item.description: Dashboard –> Differentiation and Integration Recap Constant multiplication: $[c\cdot f’]=c\cdot f’$ Sum: $[f + g]’ = f’ + g’$ Product: $[f\cdot g]’ = f’\cdot g + f\cdot g’$

item.title: Differentiation and Integration - Lesson 6
item.description: Dashboard –> Differentiation and Integration Recap Constant multiplication: $[c\cdot f’]=c\cdot f’$ Sum: $[f + g]’ = f’ + g’$ Product: $[f\cdot g]’ = f’\cdot g + f\cdot g’$

item.title: Differentiation and Integration - Lesson 7
item.description: Dashboard –> Differentiation and Integration Recap Constant multiplication: $[c\cdot f’]=c\cdot f’$ Sum: $[f + g]’ = f’ + g’$ Product: $[f\cdot g]’ = f’\cdot g + f\cdot g’$

item.title: Differentiation and Integration - Lesson 7 - Example 1
item.description: Dashboard –> Differentiation and Integration –> Lesson 7 $f(x, y) = 3xy^{2} - 7x\sin(2y) + \sqrt{x}$ Differentiate with respect to x: (y is a constant)

item.title: Differentiation and Integration - Lesson 7 - Example 2
item.description: Dashboard –> Differentiation and Integration –> Lesson 7 $f(x) = -x^{3} + 8x^{2} - 5x + 1$ The x-coordinate of $P$ is 4.

item.title: Differentiation and Integration - Lesson 7 - Example 3
item.description: Dashboard –> Differentiation and Integration –> Lesson 7 $f(x) = \frac{3x}{x^{2} + 2}$ $f’(x) = \frac{-3x^{2} + 6}{(x^{2} + 2)^{2}}$

item.title: Differentiation and Integration - Lesson 8
item.description: Dashboard –> Differentiation and Integration Primitives A primitive is the inverse of a derivative. If you take the primitive of a derivative, you end up with the base function.

item.title: Differentiation and Integration - Lesson 8 - Example 1
item.description: Dashboard –> Differentiation and Integration –> Lesson 8 $f(x) = 3x^{2} + 4x$ $f’(x) = 6x + 4$ $F(x) = x^{3} + 2x^{2} + C$

item.title: Differentiation and Integration - Lesson 9
item.description: Dashboard –> Differentiation and Integration Splitting fraction You can split up one difficult fraction into two or more easier fraction using fraction splitting.
